channel.title: Trang Bui on Trang Bui
channel.description: Recent content in Trang Bui on Trang Bui

item.title: Blog
item.description:
Media

February 17, 2023

  • 2023 CANSSI International day of women and girls in science
  • KAIST best undergraduate thesis award
  • ISEF 2012 First Prize in Mechanical and Electrical Engineering

Why is Deep Learning good?

Dec 03, 2020

Thanks to the David Sprott’s Distinguished Lecture by Professor Trevor Hastie and questions raised by Professor Ali Ghodsi in the Q&A session today, I realized that several things about Deep Learning. Why they are so good, I think there are three reasons:

  • For me, Deep Learning is just like a stack of linear models, so it is one way of ensemble models together with a certain structure, maybe hierarchical. Hence, the Deep Learning models usually contain more parameters than the classical models, which may explain why it can have better performance with bigger data. The data has been summarized by more parameters.
  • A lot of the model takes in knowledge about the data to give a good modeling. For example, the scan in CNN is just like a local kernel, which makes sense to capture the locally-correlated features in an image. Deep Learning also make use of data augmentation, just like we are adding a “gaussian cloud” to the data in classical modeling. These augmentation has more power because they are usually correct. In CNN, jittering the picture or rotating it we know that it still has the same label, i.e., we are adding in data with labels/response that we know is the true.
  • Deep Learning is online learning. It keeps updating with new data, i.e., we can use pre-train model for a new one. This makes it become very handy in a lot of applications.

item.title: Books
item.description:
Statistical books

  • Topics in Statistical Consulting - coauthor and editor together with SCCRU at University of Waterloo.

Books on my shelf

  • Van der Vaart, A. W. (2000). Asymptotic statistics (Vol. 3). Cambridge University Press.
  • Howell, D. C. (2012). Statistical methods for psychology. Cengage Learning.
  • Douglas, C. M. (2012). Design and analysis of experiments. John Wiley & Sons Ltd.
  • Harrer, M., Cuijpers, P., Furukawa, T. A., & Ebert, D. D. (2019). Doing Meta-Analysis with R: A Hands-On Guide.
  • McCulloch, C. E., & Searle, S. R. (2004). Generalized, linear, and mixed models. John Wiley & Sons.
  • Kolaczyk, E. D., & Csárdi, G. (2014). Statistical analysis of network data with R (Vol. 65). New York, NY: Springer.
  • Whittaker, J. (2009). Graphical models in applied multivariate statistics. Wiley Publishing.
  • Gelman, A., Carlin, J. B., Stern, H. S., & Rubin, D. B. (1995). Bayesian data analysis. Chapman and Hall/CRC.
  • Hernán, M. A., & Robins, J. M. (2010). Causal inference.

item.title: Research
item.description:
Papers

  • General additive network effects model - with Stefan H. Steiner and Nathaniel T. Stevens, submitted to The New England Journal of Statistics in Data Science.
  • In all fairness: A meta-analysis of the tax fairness-tax compliance literature - with Jonathan Farrar, Mary Marshall, Dawn Massey, Linda Thorne, and Anita Wu, submitted to Behavioral Research in Accounting.

Talks

  • Virtual ISI World Statistics Congress 2021, IPS69, General Linear Network Effects Model for Network Experimentation.

item.title: Teaching
item.description:
Courses

  • Analytic Methods for Business 2 Spring 2022

Teaching Assistant

During my graduate study at University of Waterloo, I work as a teaching assistant for statistics courses in the department. Below is the list of the courses that I have assisted.

  • ACTSC 231 Introductory Financial Mathematics Spring 2018
  • STAT 202 Introductory Statistics for Scientists Fall 2017
  • STAT 211 Introductory Statistics and Sampling for Accounting Winter 2019
  • STAT 230 Probability Fall 2018, Winter 2018
  • STAT 316 Introduction to Statistical Problem Solving by Computer Winter 2019
  • STAT 330 Mathematical Statistics Fall 2018, Fall 2017
  • STAT 331 Applied Linear Models Spring 2020
  • STAT 340 Computer Simulation of Complex Systems Winter 2018
  • STAT 341 Computational Statistics and Data Analysis Fall 2019
  • STAT 371 Applied Linear Models and Process Improvement for Business Head TA Spring 2018
  • STAT441/881 Statistical Learning - Classification Head TA Fall 2020, Fall 2019
